Award.AwardTitle: Reinvigorating Elementary Science through a Partnership with CA Teachers (RESPeCT):Sustainable research-based professional development with teacher leaders in a high-needs district

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Reinvigorating Elementary Science through Partnership with California Teachers (RESPeCT) project is a partnership-driven effort based on mutual trust and a shared vision among Pomona Unified School District (PUSD), California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP) as Core Partners, and the non-profit Biological Sciences Curriculum Study (BSCS) as a Supporting Partner. The RESPeCT project is developing, implementing, and studying an innovative and sustainable solution to critical problems of national importance--the unacceptable number of K-6 students who are failing to develop a rudimentary understanding of science, and the clear and persistent achievement gaps in students' understanding of science. The RESPeCT project builds on and puts into practice a successful videocase-based, analysis-of-practice professional development approach, in combination with a leadership development component, for Kindergarten through sixth grade teachers in a high-needs district. Over the five year life of the project, RESPeCT is developing a cadre of 42 K-6 Teacher Leaders, with support from CPP science and mathematics faculty, and these Teacher Leaders will sustain and lead future RESPeCT professional development efforts to reach all K-6 teachers in PUSD, supporting the teaching of challenging science content for all students. The RESPeCT Project directly benefits 168 teachers (30% of PUSD elementary teachers) and over 7,500 K-6 students and is transforming the way science is taught and learned in PUSD. Ultimately, all 511 elementary PUSD teachers and their students will benefit from the RESPeCT project. PUSD is designing a fiscal plan to continue and sustain the RESPeCT PD program and partnerships with CPP faculty far beyond the life of the project. The RESPeCT research team employs a rigorous research design, including a control group of teachers, to examine the impact of the RESPeCT professional development on PUSD students, teachers (including Teacher Leaders) and CPP faculty. RESPeCT is an Implementation project in the Current Issues Related to STEM Content focal area.

A major contribution of the RESPeCT project is the development of videocases and shared curriculum materials aligned to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) that integrate selected Common Core State Standards (CCSS) from Mathematics and English language arts (ELA) to empower teachers to teach science while relieving pressures to focus solely on mathematics and ELA. The development of fourteen modules related to life, physical, and earth and space science, concentrated within two cross-cutting concepts (energy & matter and stability & change) from the NGSS and incorporating mathematical and ELA standards is a major component of this project. The materials will be available to districts and teachers across the country. In addition, the RESPeCT project includes professional development for university faculty in leading elementary teacher learning communities. Insights into teaching and learning gained by university faculty is helping science, mathematics, and education faculty reform courses for science and mathematics majors and preservice teachers. RESPeCT serves as a national NSF-MSP model for broad-based collaborations that transform science teaching and learning. The project has special relevance for motivating and supporting teachers who serve students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Reinvigorating Elementary Science through a Partnership with California Teachers  (RESPeCT) program was a partnership, supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation, between California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP),  BSCS Science Learning (BSCS), and Pomona Unified School District. The programs goal was to study whether and how a previously-tested professional development (PD) program, Science Teachers Learning from Lesson Analysis (STeLLA), could be scaled up to reach large numbers of teachers and students in a Title I, majority Hispanic, urban district by developing a cadre of K - 6 teacher leaders to provide the STeLLA PD to their peer teachers. 

The STeLLA PD Program 

The intensive one-year STeLLA PD program was previously studied using a gold standard rigorous research design. During the program, teachers collaboratively analyzed videos of elementary science teaching and learning. In small, facilitated, grade-level study groups teachers first analyzed video from experienced STeLLA teachers classrooms. This intensive summer work deepened teachers science content understanding and introduced them to student-thinking focused core teaching strategies (Figure 1-accompanying image 2). Across the school year, teachers used STeLLA lesson plans and teaching strategies with their students. Study group sessions during the school year focused on analyzing videos of themselves teaching these lessons. 

Analyzing lesson videos and accompanying transcripts slowed down the teaching process, allowing teachers to examine more closely how teaching strategies influence student thinking and the science content storyline. Video analysis also revealed teachers science misunderstandings, providing opportunities for PD leaders to support teachers content deepening in a meaningful, teaching context. 

This videobased, analysis-of-practice approach was a new kind of work for teachers requiring a knowledgeable facilitator for each study group. How could such a program be scaled to reach large numbers of teachers and students? 

The RESPeCT Teacher Leader Development Program

The STeLLA scale-up challenge was addressed by the RESPeCT partnership team who set an ambitious agenda that included: 

  • Designing and implementing a Teacher Leader Development program to prepare a cadre of five to six teacher leaders at each grade level, grades kindergarten through six,
  • Expanding STeLLA from 4th and 5th grades to grades K-6,
  • Studying the impact on the science learning of teacher leaders, peer teachers, and students,
  • Identifying factors that contributed to successful scale-up, and 
  • Developing materials (videos, lesson plans, PD Leader guides, assessments, etc.) needed to accomplish the components above.

During Year 1 of the RESPeCT leadership program, prospective teacher leaders experienced STeLLA PD as learners. In Year 2, they learned how to lead STeLLA PD through analysis of video-recorded PD sessions and practice facilitation. In Year 3, teacher leaders worked in pairs to lead the STeLLA PD for their peers. CPP science and math faculty experts and science education experts from BSCS and CPP facilitated the grade level teams in Years 1 and 2 and supported teacher leaders self-identified learning needs in Year 3.

Results

Teacher and Student Learning. During the grant period nearly one third of Pomona Unifieds elementary teachers and 7,500 students benefited. Teacher leaders and peer teachers outperformed comparison teachers in their understanding of the targeted science content and in their ability to analyze science teaching and learning in videos of others teaching, with relatively high effect sizes indicating a strong impact.

Similarly, the 2nd - 6th grade students of the teacher leaders and the peer teachers significantly outperformed students of comparison teachers on tests measuring understanding of the science they were taught (with relatively high effect sizes indicating strong results). Results using read-aloud assistmed assessments for K-1 students showed similar patterns. 

Factors Contributing to Success. Analysis of multiple data sources revealed factors that supported RESPeCT scale-up successes which were used to develop the RESPeCT Comprehensive Scaling Framework (Figure 2-accompanying image 3). The framework includes a research and evaluation strand and an enactment strand composed of five phases (Design, Preparation, Implementation, Transfer of Ownership, and Sustainability). Scaling does not begin until a precursor phase demonstrates strong impact on student learning. Four themes run throughout the work: a) Focus on the big picture: Teacher and student learning; b) Attention to detail: Organization and communication, c) Sufficient time in six aspects of the work, and d) Partnership, people, and respect. 

Broader Impacts

While RESPeCT focused on one Title I district, its successes suggest the value of using the RESPeCT Teacher Leadership Development program to implement STeLLA PD in more districts across the country. The RESPeCT framework can also guide scaling of other partnership-driven education interventions. 

The RESPeCT Comprehensive Scaling Framework also advances scaling research by conceptualizing scaling more fully in both its research and enactment aspects. Future research can examine factors needed for successful scaling in a wider variety of contexts.

Pomona Unfied teacher leaders continue to offer the STeLLA PD with the goal of reaching all K-6 teachers.  Materials developed during the grant are available at: https://www.cpp.edu/respect/index.shtml
